conversation.content: So, um, I heard you're, like, opening your own bar next month, actually?
Yes! After twelve years behind other people's [speeding up] bars, I finally secured the investors and found the perfect location downtown near the arts district.
That's, well, incredible, you know, I mean, your own place finally.
It's been a long journey, honestly, from washing glasses at dive bars to, er, studying mixology in Tokyo, but every step taught me something essential about this craft.
Uh, how much did you, basically, have to save up for this, I guess?
Between my savings and three angel investors, we raised about four hundred thousand, which covers renovation, licensing, initial inventory, and six months of operating expenses.
Four hundred thousand dollars?
I know it sounds [very slowly] like a lot, but, hmm, the profit margins in this industry are actually quite good if you, well, manage inventory properly and create the right atmosphere.
What's your [very quickly] concept going to be?
Pre-Prohibition era cocktails with, um, modern techniques, featuring house-made bitters and, sort of, locally sourced ingredients, plus we'll have live jazz Thursday through Saturday nights.
That sounds sophisticated.
Sophisticated but approachable is exactly what we're aiming for, with cocktails ranging from twelve to eighteen dollars and a strong emphasis on educating customers about cocktail history.
Er, are you nervous about, you know, failing or, honestly, losing everything?
Of course I'm nervous, but fear [mumbling] of failure can't stop you from pursuing your dreams, and I've planned for every contingency I can think of.
Well, what if, uhh, nobody shows up, I mean, on opening night or whatever?
We've already pre-sold two hundred tickets [confidently] for our soft opening, and my regular customers from my current bar have been spreading the word for months.
You pre-sold tickets to a bar opening?
It includes five craft cocktails, [sneeze] appetizers, and live entertainment, so it's really more of an exclusive tasting event than just a regular opening.
I'm, actually, really [very melancholic] proud of you, you know, for achieving this, honestly.
Thank you, that means everything. This dream started [hesitantly] fifteen years ago when I was just a broke college student who loved making drinks, and now it's actually happening.
